TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua sitsuayan a tsautsau se Pełeti ła Dakudakuts namepałi.
izoa sicoayan a caocao se Peljeti lja Dakodakoc namepalji.
S.TRANSL: Once upon a time there was a person from Pełeti of the Dakudakuts clan who became an evil-eye man.

S.FORM: nu patsun ta lalangaw, ta qatsang, ta kuka, ta tsautsau, matsay sakamaya penułat, aya.
no pacon ta lalangaw, ta qacang, ta koka, ta caocao, macay sakamaya penoljat, aya.
S.TRANSL: If he looked at flies, pigs, chicken or people, they all just died, they say.

S.FORM: marekutj a sikataqałan, sa kemim ta umaq.
marekotj a sikataqaljan, sa kemim ta omaq.
S.TRANSL: The villagers were afraid, and looked for somewhere for him to live.

S.FORM: djemumak anga i sadip ta tjaguł; saka seman umaq; sa sematjez anga pasa zua a sikataqałan.
djemomak anga i sadip ta tjagolj; saka seman omaq; sa sematjez anga pasa zoa a sikataqaljan.
S.TRANSL: They found a rock-face in the foothills and made a house there; and the villagers sent him there.

S.FORM: saka pavaivai anga sakamaya senemanemanga, patje se Tenatseng a qinałan a pairang.
saka pavaivai anga sakamaya senemanemanga, patje se Tenaceng a qinaljan a pairang.
S.TRANSL: People from everywhere gave him food, including the plainspeople in the village of Tenatseng.

S.FORM: saka masutan aravats a senemanemanga.
saka masotan aravac a senemanemanga.
S.TRANSL: So everyone lost heavily,

S.FORM: saka limutseng a pairang, sa "ari, qemtsii," aya małavar tia pairang.
saka limoceng a pairang, sa "ari, qemcii," aya maljavar tia pairang.
S.TRANSL: and the plainspeople got angry, and decided: “Come on, let’s kill him.”

S.FORM: vaik a sema zua i ta umaq ni pałi, sa djemałun anga.
vaik a sema zoa i ta omaq ni palji, sa djemaljon anga.
S.TRANSL: They went to the evil-eye man’s house. When they got there,

S.FORM: "kiqiłau.
"kiqiljao.
S.TRANSL: they said: “Hide yourself.

S.FORM: mangtjez amen a pavay ta lami."
mangtjez amen a pavay ta lami."
S.TRANSL: We’ve come to give you food.”

S.FORM: sa kembung timadju a pałi; sa qetsin na pairang azua timadju a pałi.
sa kembong timadjo a palji; sa qecin na pairang azoa timadjo a palji.
S.TRANSL: So the evil-eye man bent down, and the plainspeople killed him.

S.FORM: manu mitsetsikal ti pałi; pavalet a patsun.
mano micecikal ti palji; pavalet a pacon.
S.TRANSL: But the evil-eye man became violent and looked at them in revenge;

S.FORM: saka matsay anga sakamaya a pairang.
saka macay anga sakamaya a pairang.
S.TRANSL: and the plainspeople just died.

S.FORM: mapułu anga a tjeza a matsay.
mapoljo anga a tjeza a macay.
S.TRANSL: Only a few survived and didn’t die.

S.FORM: saka matsay ti pałi, sa kiquluan, sa tsavuin ta sitsavuan, sa kematsu sema umaq.
saka macay ti palji, sa kiqoloan, sa cavoin ta sicavoan, sa kemaco sema omaq.
S.TRANSL: So the evil-eye man died, and they cut off his head, and wrapped it in a blanket; and brought it home.

S.FORM: sa mangtjez i umaq, saka semutsavu.
sa mangtjez i omaq, saka semocavo.
S.TRANSL: When they got home, they unwrapped it.

S.FORM: tjuruvu a łemizaw a qaqunuan vavayavayan.
tjorovo a ljemizaw a qaqonoan vavayavayan.
S.TRANSL: There were many children and women watching.

S.FORM: manu patsun ta matsa, kimatsay anga a mapułat.
mano pacon ta maca, kimacay anga a mapoljat.
S.TRANSL: And by looking at the evil-eye man’s eyes they all killed themselves.

S.FORM: sa "nakuya," aya azua tjeza a matsay; sa sematjez pasa pana i taladj ta vatsał.
sa "nakoya," aya azoa tjeza a macay; sa sematjez pasa pana i taladj ta vacalj.
S.TRANSL: “That’s bad,” said those who survived and didn’t die. So they took the head to the river to a deep pool.

S.FORM: saka palisi anga palalaut.
saka palisi anga palalaot.
S.TRANSL: Ever since it is taboo to go there.

S.FORM: nu sema zua, kisaqetju anga sakamaya, aya.
no sema zoa, kisaqetjo anga sakamaya, aya.
S.TRANSL: They say that those who go there bring illness on themselves.
amin
